subtitle: steps to realization a class lecture
delivered in America first among the
qualifications required for the aspirant
of jhana or wisdom come Shama and Dhamma
which may be taken together they mean
the keeping of the organs and their own
centers without allowing them to stray
out
I should explain to you first what the
word organ means here are the eyes the
eyes are not the organs of vision but
only the instruments unless the organs
also are present I cannot see even if I
have eyes but given both the organs and
the instruments unless the mind attaches
itself to these two no vision takes
place so in each act of perception three
things are necessary first the external
instruments then the internal organs and
lastly the mind if any one of them be
absent then there will be no perception
thus the mind acts through two agencies
one external and the other internal when
I see things my mind goes out becomes
external eyes but suppose I close my
eyes and begin to think the mind does
not go out it is internally active but
in either case there is activity of the
organs when I look at you and speak to
you both the organs and the instruments
are active when I close my eyes and
begin to think the organs are active but
not the instruments without the activity
of these organs
there will be no thought you will find
that none of you can think without some
symbol in the case of the blind man he
is also to think through some figure the
organs of sight and hearing are
generally very active you must bear in
mind by the word organ is meant the
nerve center in the brain the eyes and
ears are only the instruments of seen
and hearing and the organs are inside if
the organs are destroyed by any means
even if the eyes are the ears be there
we shall not see or hear so in order to
control the mind we must first be able
to control these organs to restrain the
mind from wandering outward or inward
and keep the organs in their respective
centers is what is meant by the words
Schama and dama Shama consists in not
allowing the mind to externalize and
dhamma in checking the external
instruments
now comes you parati which consists in
not thinking of things of the senses
most of our time is spent in thinking
about sense objects things which we have
seen or which we have heard which we
shall see or she'll hear things which we
have eaten or eating or shall eat places
where we have lived and so on we think
of them or talk of them most of our time
one who wishes to be of a Dantan must
give up this habit then comes a next
preparation it is a hard task to be a
philosopher today cushaw the most
difficult of law it is nothing less than
the ideal forbearance resist not evil
this requires a little explanation
we may not resist an evil but at the
same time we may feel very miserable a
man may say very harsh things to me and
I may not outwardly hate him for it may
not answer him back and may restrain
myself from apparently getting angry but
anger and hatred may be in my mind and I

is not non-resistance I should be
without any Fein of hatred or anger
without any thought of resistance my
mind must then be as calm as if nothing

resistance and not before
forbearance of all razors without even a
thought of resisting or driving it out
without even any painful feeling in the
mind or any remorse
this is to diksha suppose I do not

if I have to dig sha I should no feel
any remorse for not having resisted when
the mind has attained to that state it
has become established into cha people
in India do extraordinary things in

a foreign thing the next qualification
required is Shraddha faith one must have

until one has it one cannot aspire to be
jolly a great sage once told me that not
one in 20 million in his
believed in God I asked him why and he
said suppose there's a thief in this
room and he gets to know that there's a
mass of gold in a next room and only a
very thin partition between the two
rooms what would be the condition of
that thief
I answered he will not be able to sleep
at all his brain will be actively
thinking of some means of getting at the
gold and he will think of nothing else
then he replied do you believe that a
man could believe in God and not go mad
to get him if a man sincerely believes
that there is that immense infinite mine
of bliss and that it can be reached
would not that man go mad and his
struggle to reach it strong faith in God
and a consequent eagerness to reach him
constitute Shradha then comes some
Madonna or constant practice to hold the
mind in God nothing is done in a day
religion cannot be swallowed in the form

holds you that ye live and die and whirl
upon the wheel and hug and kiss its

have is of our own choosing
such as our nature the old who
having been kept in prison for sixty
years was released on the coronation of
noon Emperor exclaimed when he came out
that he could not live he must go back
to his horrible dungeon among the rats
and mice he could not bear the light so
he asked them to kill him or send him

exactly similar is the condition of all
men
we run headlong after all sorts of
misery and are unwilling to be freed
from them every day we run after

mad pursuit but on and on we go blinded

have a piece of wood protruding from the
York and on that is fastened - whispers
bra strong the Bullock is blindfolded in
such a way that it can only look forward
and so it stretches its neck to get to
the straw in doing so it pushes a piece
of wood out a little further and it
makes another attempt with the same
result in yet another and so on
it never catches a straw but goes round
and round in the hope of getting it and
in so doing grinds out the oil in the
same way you and who are born slaves to
nature money and wealth wives and
children are always chasing a wisp of
straw a mere chime ehre
and are going through an innumerable
round of lives without obtaining what we
seek the great dream is love we are all
going to love and to be loved we are all
going to be happy and never meet with
misery but the more we go towards
happiness the more it goes away from us
thus the world is going on society goes

happiness there is than them and how
little in truth you have gained in the

and cruces the king said to the great

happiest man I have not seen anyone very
happy nonsense at Croesus I am the
happiest man in the world wait sir till

replied the sage and went away in course
of time the king was conquered by the
Persians and they ordered him to be
burnt alive the funeral pier was
prepared and worn when poor cruces saw
it he cried aloud Solan Solan on being
asked to whom he referred he told his
story and the Persian Emperor was
touched and save his life such as a life
story of each one of us such as a
tremendous power of nature over us it

are always hoping against hope this hope
this chime mera Madden's us we are
always hoping for happiness there was
once a great king in ancient India who
was once asked four questions of which
one was what is the most wonderful thing
in the world
hope was the answer this is the most
wonderful thing day and night we see
people dying around us and yet we think
we shall not die we never think that we
shall die or that we shall suffer each
man thinks that success will be his
hoping against hope against all odds
against all mathematical reasoning
nobody is ever really happy here if a
man be wealthy and have plenty to eat
his digestion is out of order and he
cannot eat if a man's digestion be good
and we have the digestive power of a
cormorant he has nothing to put into his

if he be hungry and poor he has a whole
regiment of children and does not know
what to do with them why is it so
because happiness and misery are the
obverse and reverse of the same coin he
who takes happiness must take misery
also we all have this foolish idea that
we can have happiness without misery and
it has taken such possession of us that
we have no control of the senses when I
was in Boston a young man came up to me
and gave me a scrap of paper on which he
had written a name and an address
followed by these words all the wealth
and all the happiness of the world are
yours if you only know how to get them
if you come to me I will teach you how
to get them charge five dollars he gave
me this incent what do you think of this
I said young man why don't you get the
money to print this you don't even have
enough money to get this printed he did
not understand he was infatuated with
the idea that he could get immense
wealth and happiness without any trouble
there are two extremes into which men
are running one is extreme optimism when
everything is rosy and nice and good the
other extreme pessimism when everything

men have more or less undeveloped brains
one the million we see with a

it is derogatory to the glory of man

here comes under the reaction the
